Award.AwardTitle: Acquisition and Development of ICP-MS Instrumentation for Ocean Science Research at the University of Minnesota
Award.AbstractNarration: This award purchases a new Inductively Coupled Mass Spectrometer (ICP-MS) for geosciences research at the University of Minnesota. The instrument is used to support analyses of seafloor hydrothermal vent fluids and other geological materials, as well as train graduate and undergraduate students in state-of-the art geochemical techniques. The institution has provided a strong commitment to the sustainability of the instrument by improving the associated laboratory facilities and providing technical support. NSF-related broader impacts of the purchase are primarily in building infrastructure for science at the host institution, student training, and support of research for a faculty member whose gender is under-represented in the sciences.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project funds were used to acquire a piece of equipment (Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass-Spectrometer) for analysis of the chemical composition of seawater and other aqueous fluids. The PI and Co-PI have the routine need to study changes in the chemistry of fluids as a result of reaction with rocks beneath the ocean floor. The compositionally modified fluid often is returned to the ocean as spectacular vents where temperatures can exceed 350°C. The composition of the vent fluid helps to maintain the chemistry of the oceans at present values, while also providing nutrients needed for the existence of microbacteria and other animals that inhabit the vent environment. In addition to using the instrumentation for measurement of the chemistry of hydrothermal vent fluids, the equipment is also used by undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Minnesota where they gain valuable experience with state of the art research equipment that prepares them for a career in science. Thus, the NSF funded research equipment plays a direct role in facilitating research progress on an important and timely topic in the Earth Sciences (marine hydrothermal systems), while also contributing more broadly to the education of the next generation of science students in the United States.
